articles.headline: Oregon Shooting at Umpqua College Kills 10, Sheriff Says
articles.snippet: Officials said Chris Harper Mercer, 26, went on a shooting rampage in Roseburg, Ore., and that he died after an exchange of gunfire with the police.
articles.abstract: Officials said Chris Harper Mercer, 26, went on a shooting rampage in Roseburg, Ore., and that he died after an exchange of gunfire with the police.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROSEBURG, Ore. — A 26-year-old man opened fire on a community college campus here in a rampage that left 10 people dead and seven wounded and turned this rural stretch of southern Oregon into the latest American locale ravaged by a mass shooting.
articles.byline: By Dirk Vanderhart, Kirk Johnson and Julie Turkewitz

articles.headline: #ShoutYourAbortion Gets Angry Shouts Back
articles.snippet: The reactions to a campaign encouraging women who have kept their abortions secret to speak up have shown how volatile and emotional the issue remains.
articles.abstract: The reactions to a campaign encouraging women who have kept their abortions secret to speak up have shown how volatile and emotional the issue remains.
articles.lead_paragraph: It began as a challenge on the Internet: Shout your abortion.

articles.headline: Obama Condemns ‘Routine’ of Mass Shootings, Says U.S. Has Become Numb
articles.snippet: During a televised statement from the White House, the president lashed out at those who oppose gun limits by saying that their answer to such tragedies is more guns, not fewer.
articles.abstract: During a televised statement from the White House, the president lashed out at those who oppose gun limits by saying that their answer to such tragedies is more guns, not fewer.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s rage about gun massacres, building for years, spilled out Thursday night as he acknowledged his own powerlessness to prevent another tragedy and pleaded with voters to force change themselves.
articles.byline: By Gardiner Harris and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: College Rankings Fail to Measure the Influence of the Institution
articles.snippet: The new College Scorecard tells how much graduates of particular colleges earn, but not what impact, if any, the colleges have on graduates’ earnings.
articles.abstract: The new College Scorecard tells how much graduates of particular colleges earn, but not what impact, if any, the colleges have on graduates’ earnings.
articles.lead_paragraph: Students, parents and educators increasingly obsessed with college rankings have a new tool: the Obama administration’s College Scorecard. The new database focuses on a college’s graduation rate, its students’ median earnings 10 years after entering the institution and the percentage of students paying back their college loans.

articles.headline: U.A.W. Contract Vote at Fiat Chrysler Takes a Populist Tone
articles.snippet: A deal by the union’s leadership and the automaker was soundly rejected by rank-and-file workers, who “feel like the leadership has insulted them,” as one autoworker put it.
articles.abstract: A deal by the union’s leadership and the automaker was soundly rejected by rank-and-file workers, who “feel like the leadership has insulted them,” as one autoworker put it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With Donald Trump and other political outsiders towering over Jeb Bush and the rest of the Republican presidential field, Bernie Sanders surging past Hillary Clinton in early polling in New Hampshire, and executives like Don Thompson, the former McDonald’s chief, ousted in the face of declining sales and labor strife, it is clearly not a good time to be an establishment figure.

articles.headline: Amazon to Stop Selling Apple TV and Chromecast
articles.snippet: The unusual move for Amazon is not about retail sales, but rather about shoring up its Fire TV streaming devices, which are crucial to its vision for the future.
articles.abstract: The unusual move for Amazon is not about retail sales, but rather about shoring up its Fire TV streaming devices, which are crucial to its vision for the future.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Amazon said on Thursday that it would stop selling devices from Apple and Google that compete with its own streaming media players, escalating the entertainment battle between the major tech companies.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld and Katie Benner

articles.headline: Vladimir Putin Plunges Into a Caldron in Syria: Saving Assad
articles.snippet: Mr. Putin can achieve short-term goals, but analysts say efforts to restore President Bashar al-Assad’s control to all of Syria will be hindered by the civil war’s grim realities.
articles.abstract: Mr. Putin can achieve short-term goals, but analysts say efforts to restore President Bashar al-Assad’s control to all of Syria will be hindered by the civil war’s grim realities.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — After two days of attacks directed exclusively against insurgents opposed to the Syrian government, there is little question that Russia is determined to re-establish President Bashar al-Assad as Syria’s leader.
articles.byline: By Anne Barnard and Neil MacFarquhar

articles.headline: Matthias Müller, in the Driver’s Seat at Volkswagen
articles.snippet: The new head of Volkswagen, a racing enthusiast who has spoken out for migrants, is not the usual German executive. But some worry he might not be the right person to change VW’s culture.
articles.abstract: The new head of Volkswagen, a racing enthusiast who has spoken out for migrants, is not the usual German executive. But some worry he might not be the right person to change VW’s culture.
articles.lead_paragraph: Matthias Müller, Volkswagen’s new chief executive, has not been the typical button-down German executive.
articles.byline: By Danny Hakim and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Oregon Killer Described as Man of Few Words, Except on Topic of Guns
articles.snippet: Christopher Harper-Mercer, identified as the gunman who killed nine people in Oregon, left behind 13 guns and a list of online grievances.
articles.abstract: Christopher Harper-Mercer, identified as the gunman who killed nine people in Oregon, left behind 13 guns and a list of online grievances.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROSEBURG, Ore. — Christopher Harper-Mercer was withdrawn and quiet as he grew up in southern California, spending most of his time indoors at his mother’s apartment and deflecting neighbors when they asked him how he was doing, or why he always wore the same outfit of combat boots and green Army pants. But there was one subject that got him to open up: guns.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy and Ian Lovett

articles.headline: Grim Jobs Report Is Likely to Delay a Move by the Fed on Rates
articles.snippet: The Labor Department reported a gain of 142,000 jobs in September, and the August figure was revised downward, though unemployment remained at 5.1 percent.
articles.abstract: The Labor Department reported a gain of 142,000 jobs in September, and the August figure was revised downward, though unemployment remained at 5.1 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Unexpectedly dismal job growth last month cast a shadow on the nation’s economy, as a government report on Friday sent analysts scrambling for adjectives like “dreadful,” “a body blow” and “grim” to describe just how disappointing they found the latest employment figures.

articles.headline: Before Pope Francis Met Kim Davis, He Met With Gay Ex-Student
articles.snippet: A gay man, a former student of Francis, met the pope before the Kentucky clerk did, and the Vatican said the meeting with Ms. Davis was not an endorsement of her views.
articles.abstract: A gay man, a former student of Francis, met the pope before the Kentucky clerk did, and the Vatican said the meeting with Ms. Davis was not an endorsement of her views.
articles.lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Ever since it became public that Pope Francis met in Washington with Kim Davis, the Kentucky county clerk who refused to issue marriage licenses for same-sex couples, the questions have been swirling: Why did he meet with her, and was it meant as a political statement?
articles.byline: By Jim Yardley and Laurie Goodstein

articles.headline: Jeb Bush’s Remarks About Blacks Echo a Showdown He Faced as Governor
articles.snippet: Comments last week by Mr. Bush that outraged opponents brought to mind one of the most turbulent episodes of his governorship: a pitched battle over affirmative action.
articles.abstract: Comments last week by Mr. Bush that outraged opponents brought to mind one of the most turbulent episodes of his governorship: a pitched battle over affirmative action.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 1999, shortly after Jeb Bush’s election as governor of Florida, the leader of a national movement to overturn affirmative action policies visited his Tallahassee office with a request: Would Mr. Bush support a ballot measure banishing such policies, which had become a favored conservative target?

articles.headline: The Decline of ‘Big Soda’
articles.snippet: The drop in soda consumption represents the single largest change in the American diet in the last decade.
articles.abstract: The drop in soda consumption represents the single largest change in the American diet in the last decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: Five years ago, Mayor Michael A. Nutter proposed a tax on soda in Philadelphia, and the industry rose up to beat it back.

articles.headline: Obama Sees Russia Failing in Syria Effort
articles.snippet: Russia showed no hint of heeding Western demands to avoid bombing of fighters pushing to oust Syria’s weakened, Kremlin-backed president, Bashar al-Assad.
articles.abstract: Russia showed no hint of heeding Western demands to avoid bombing of fighters pushing to oust Syria’s weakened, Kremlin-backed president, Bashar al-Assad.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The already fragmented battlefield in Syria grew even more complicated on Friday, as Russia and Iran expanded their military efforts to defend the beleaguered Syrian government in defiance of President Obama, who predicted that their actions would lead only to a “quagmire.”
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Neil MacFarquhar

articles.headline: A Tax to Curb Excessive Trading Could Be a Boon to Returns
articles.snippet: The presidential campaign of Bernie Sanders has proposed to tax stock and bond trades. How might the idea affect investor behavior and long-term returns?
articles.abstract: The presidential campaign of Bernie Sanders has proposed to tax stock and bond trades. How might the idea affect investor behavior and long-term returns?
articles.lead_paragraph: Taxes are inevitable. Most people don’t like them. But once in a while, someone proposes a new one that could prompt the sort of behavioral change that may actually save some people money.

articles.headline: Valeant’s High-Price Drug Strategy
articles.snippet: Valeant, which has grown by acquiring rivals and slashing their staffs, has drawn the ire of a House panel, which is now considering a subpoena on the company’s price increases.
articles.abstract: Valeant, which has grown by acquiring rivals and slashing their staffs, has drawn the ire of a House panel, which is now considering a subpoena on the company’s price increases.
articles.lead_paragraph: Talk about a reversal of fortune.
